abstract.p: American University Prof Nancy D Polikoff letter responds to Sept 17 editorial on Australian Prime Min John Howard's unwillingness to apologize for policy of forcible removal of light-skinnex Aboriginal children from their families; holds that US government for many decades had almost identical policy of removal of Native American children from their families

block.p: Your Sept. 17 editorial ''The Other Australia'' highlights Prime Minister John Howard's unwillingness to apologize for the policy of forcible removal of light-skinned Aboriginal children from their families and communities over many decades. Your Sept. 17 editorial ''The Other Australia'' highlights Prime Minister John Howard's unwillingness to apologize for the policy of forcible removal of light-skinned Aboriginal children from their families and communities over many decades. Apologizing was one of the recommendations of a truth commission that documented the experiences of hundreds of victims of the policy.

Many Americans are unaware that for decades our own government had an almost identical policy of removal of Native American children from their families and tribal communities. This did not end until 1978, when it was halted by the Indian Child Welfare Act. Victims of this policy -- parents, children and their descendants -- are still alive and should have their stories recorded and preserved. An official report is a necessary step toward reconciliation between Native and non-Native Americans.
The writer is a professor of law at American University.
